article: My classmate Jennifer and I graduated from an ordinary normal university last year. Like most of the students who had just stepped out of university, we had to go through the first tough test ---- job hunting to _ a passport to society. And the most _ part was the job interview.  The _ was very fierce. Dozens of my classmates, Jennifer _ , sent our curriculum vitas to a key middle school for a teaching job, making the chance of success as low as 1 to 20.  Before the job interview, I _ complete preparations, including a formal suit, a newly-done hair, a few _ on job interviews, and even some ancient Chinese poems in case I faced a learned interviewer. On that day everything went very _ . I answered all the questions fluently. So I felt very _ to get this job. Jennifer was still there waiting for her turn. I made a "V" _ to her. She smiled at me, looking a little worried. I _ she was not as eloquent as I, though not worse than me in studies. I felt I had an advantage over her. However, a week later, all of us received letters of _ . Another week later, guess what happened! She got the job! _ congratulating her, I asked her how she got it. She said, "I did _ . I just wrote them a note of thanks after receiving the letter of refusal." Only then _ I realize why all the applicants had received the same letters and that was also a part of the _ . Only a note of thanks, but that was what made all the difference. This experience _ me a good lesson, that is, _ excellent you are, you should never forget the _ manners of saying "Thank you!".
